Award.AwardTitle: NSF Travel Grant Support for Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) WiSec 2015 Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
WiSec is one of the leading international conferences on the security and privacy of wireless communications and mobile networks. Every year, researchers present novel ideas and fundamental advances in areas including location privacy, anonymity, security of smartphones, jamming attacks and defenses, and usable mobile security. WiSec serves to foster communication among researchers and practitioners with a common interest in improving the security of wireless networks and devices through scientific and technological innovation.

This award will support travel costs for graduate students to attend the WiSec conference, to be held in New York City NY in June 2015, allowing them to interact with experts in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION

WiSec is one of the leading international conferences on privacy andsecurity of wireless networks, wireless communication and mobiledevices. ACM, the Association for Computing Machinery, is the technicalsponsor of WiSec, and has been providing logistic and economic supportfor all past conferences. The conference has been held annually since2008, when the ACM Workshop on Wireless Security (2002-2007), the ACMWorkshop on Security of Ad Hoc and Sensor Networks (2003-2007), and theEuropean Workshop on the Security of Ad Hoc and Sensor Networks(2004-2007) were merged into WiSec. It is one of the main forums whereresearchers and practitioners are free to share and discuss a widevariety of scientific ideas for improving security, privacy andanonymity of mobile devices and wireless networks. With increasedrecognition of the importance of security in mobile networks anddevices, interest in WiSec has surged in recent years.
The goal of this project was to provide financial support for domesticstudents to attend WiSec 2015. Attending conferences is an importantpart of their educational experience, and students often have limitedtravel funds.


WISEC 2015 STATISTICS

WiSec 2015 had a total of 83 registered attendees. The conferenceaccepted 25 papers out of 131 submissions (19% acceptance rate), and 9posters/demos. The conference program included two keynotes: the first,on June 24 (Why we should build a Secure Positioning Infrastructure, Dr.Srdjan Capkun, ETH Zurich); the second, on June 25 (Security for Low-EndIoT Devices: When Energy is Not Enough, What is One to Do? Wade Trappe,Rutgers University).


ACCOMPLISHMENTS

This Grant allowed four students to travel attend ACM WiSec 2015. Thestudents greatly benefited from attending WiSec, because the conferenceprovided a unique opportunity to interact with the members of thewireless and smartphone security and privacy community. Practitionersand members of the scientific community attended the conference, andshare their ideas with the students.
WiSec 2015 was co-located with RFIDsec 2015, one of the earliestworkshops devoted to security and privacy in radio-frequencyidentification (RFID) devices. This provided the students with theopportunity to attend two leading events in the security, privacy, andanonymity landscape.
